awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2019:  Leaky Landscapes:  Using Arctic catchments to assess ecosystem 'openness'
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2019, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The project seeks to understand the connection between land and aquatic ecosystems in a warming Arctic. This scientific challenge has been identified by the international community and Long-Term Ecological Research (LTER) field stations in the Arctic. The Arctic ecosystem is being altered rapidly and systematically as a result of the changing climate. One critical element of change is permafrost thaw, which allows previously trapped nutrients to 'leak' in Arctic landscapes, although there is little agreement about the ultimate fate of the leaked material. To fill this knowledge gap, the project will use continuous and geographically extensive monitoring of river water quality to reveal landscape features that influence nutrient release from land to streams. In addition, the fellow will enhance public awareness of unique but globally-significant Arctic ecosystems through the use of technology to bridge the field to classroom gap. Hosted at Michigan State University, the fellow will work in partnership with the Arctic LTER at Toolik Field Station and Kellogg Biological Station LTER.

The postdoctoral fellow will use existing and planned LTER data collection to integrate Arctic ecological understanding at the plot and watershed-scales. The project will create a number of research products with broad interest to hydrologists, ecologists, and biogeochemists, including: 1) Analyses of synoptic and continuous data of catchment hydrology and hydrochemistry that have not yet been applied to the Arctic, and 2) Improved fundamental understanding of Arctic ecosystem 'hotspots' for nutrient fluxes. Further, the research is integrated with an education plan aimed at increasing participation of under-represented groups in Arctic research in three stages: 1) Developing K-12 lesson plans in partnership with Kellogg Biological Station Teacher Training Workshops, 2) Publishing these teaching plans as open-source Data Nuggets, and 3) Reaching K-12 classrooms through the free and broad-reaching 'Skype a Scientist' program. The project will expand current efforts at Michigan State University and the Arctic LTER aimed at understanding hydrochemical fate and transport, and will directly link to the Kellogg Biological Station LTER's outreach mission.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Arctic landscapes are experiencing profound ecological change, releasing carbon and nutrients previously frozen in permafrost that become participant in local and regional biogeochemical cycles. However, across the vast Arctic, there is a significant knowledge gap in constraining how coupled terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems will respond to increased material export from degrading permafrost; in fact, there is still no current consensus between plot- and regional-scale understanding of the fate of this liberated material. Plot-scale studies indicate that released nutrients are tightly cycled within terrestrial ecosystem components, while regional-scale river exports indicate nutrients are leaked from terrestrial to aquatic ecosystems. Though these complex interactions are challenging to quantify, water chemistry and flow in river networks integrate terrestrial and aquatic ecosystem processes, potentially providing a pathway for detecting and understanding ecological change. As an NSF post-doctoral fellow at Michigan State University, my research efforts were aimed at using river chemistry to detect patterns of permafrost ecosystem “leakiness” to carbon and nutrient loss.

The primary research project was designed to resolve when, where, and how carbon and nutrient exports occur from changing Arctic landscapes. The research addressed the following key questions: When in the thaw season are Arctic landscapes systematically more “open” to DOC and NO3- loss, Where are Arctic landscapes more “open” or “closed”, and finally, What are the primary controls on Arctic landscape “openness”? To answer these questions, I leveraged existing data from the Arctic LTER and augmented ongoing data collection efforts at Toolik Field Station on the North Slope of Alaska, including (1) existing data from repeated spatially intense synoptic sampling of ~50 nested subcatchments across several Arctic watersheds and (2) the deployment of high-frequency, semi-autonomous water quality sensors. My project targeted three study watersheds representative of important distinct landscapes on the Alaskan North Slope: alpine, low-gradient tundra, and lake-influenced wet acidic tundra. Using these data, I applied several novel hydrologic indices that improve our ability to link surface water chemistry with landscape-level observations. There were several key findings from this project. First, I used a literature meta-analysis to show that that Arctic researchers from nearly all environmental science disciplines are understudying periods of rapid change in environmental conditions, such as the Arctic “shoulder seasons” of early snow melt and late thaw season. This sampling bias limits our ability to track the fate of carbon and nutrients within Arctic ecosystems. A second key finding from this project demonstrated that high flow events (i.e., storms) serve as intense moments that can disproportionately export carbon and nitrate as river flow increases. However, the direction and magnitude of these patterns were largely driven by landscape characteristics and timing of the storm during the thaw season. Finally, data synthesized for this project help document the unique role of landscape features, such as stream-lake interactions, on controlling the spatial distribution of water chemistry in rivers near Toolik Field Station. 

Outside my primary research project efforts, I engaged in several activities that promote diversity, equity, and inclusion in STEM. Over the course of my fellowship, I worked with the Kellogg Biological Station K12 Partnership Program to develop two interactive, data-driven lesson plans to bring the Arctic to the lower 48 states. After iterating the lesson plans partnering with the teachers and KBS education staff, these Data Nuggets have been published online and are openly available for use in classrooms. In addition, I participated in several Skype a Scientist calls, which allowed me to virtually engage with K12 classrooms.
